paragraphs.text:
%md

## Kafka Streams Demo

#### This notebook presents a sample Kafka Streams program

This example is self-contained and doesn't have any dependency on external data or other notebooks, just simple illustration purpose.

There are 4 programs in the paragraèhs below

0. Shell script to create required kafka topics
1. The Kafa Streams demo program itself (neverending)
2. A simple program used to stop the Kafka Stream demo program
3. A kafka consummer used to show the results of the Kafka Streams program demo
3. A kafka producer used to send data to the Kakfa Streams program demo

msg.data:
Kafka Streams Demo

This notebook presents a sample Kafka Streams program

This example is self-contained and doesn’t have any dependency on external data or other notebooks, just simple illustration purpose.

There are 4 programs in the paragraèhs below

  1. Shell script to create required kafka topics
  2. The Kafa Streams demo program itself (neverending)
  3. A simple program used to stop the Kafka Stream demo program
  4. A kafka consummer used to show the results of the Kafka Streams program demo
  5. A kafka producer used to send data to the Kakfa Streams program demo

paragraphs.text:
%md

## 0. Required kafka topics

*Run following paragraph to create potentially missing kafka topics*

msg.data:
0. Required kafka topics

Run following paragraph to create potentially missing kafka topics

paragraphs.text:
%sh

. /etc/eskimo_topology.sh

if [[ `kafka-topics.sh --zookeeper $MASTER_ZOOKEEPER_1:2181 --describe | grep -E "Topic: streams-plaintext-input[^-]+"` == "" ]]; then

    kafka-topics.sh \
        --create \
        --replication-factor 1 \
        --partitions 1 \
        --zookeeper $MASTER_ZOOKEEPER_1:2181 \
        --topic streams-plaintext-input
fi

if [[ `kafka-topics.sh --zookeeper $MASTER_ZOOKEEPER_1:2181 --describe | grep -E "Topic: streams-wordcount-output[^-]+"` == "" ]]; then

    kafka-topics.sh \
        --create \
        --replication-factor 1 \
        --partitions 4 \
        --zookeeper $MASTER_ZOOKEEPER_1:2181 \
        --topic streams-wordcount-output
fi

%md

## 1. Kafka Streams Wordcount program

*This paragrah launches the kafka streams Wordcount program itself*
The Zeppelin Java interpreter compiles the followin class and then executes its main method in its own JVM.
The name of the class is rewritten at compile time and a random class name is generated, which makes it unfortunately impossible to share static variables between paragraphs.

**One needs to use the program 2. Kill Kafka Streams program (with whole Java interpreter) three paragraph further to stop this program once it is running.**

msg.data:
1. Kafka Streams Wordcount program

This paragrah launches the kafka streams Wordcount program itself
The Zeppelin Java interpreter compiles the followin class and then executes its main method in its own JVM.
The name of the class is rewritten at compile time and a random class name is generated, which makes it unfortunately impossible to share static variables between paragraphs.

One needs to use the program 2. Kill Kafka Streams program (with whole Java interpreter) three paragraph further to stop this program once it is running.

paragraphs.text:
%md

## 2. Kill Kafka Streams program (with whole Java interpreter)

*This second paragraph is used to stop the Kafka Streams program launched by the previous paragraph*
Unfortunately, since programs run through the Java interpreter are executed in the interpreter JVM itself, and because the name of the class above is regenerated at compile time (which makes it impossible for instance to use status variables in another paragraph), an artifice needs to be found to stop it.
*So here we're using a control file whose deletion forces stop the kafka stream program above*

msg.data:
2. Kill Kafka Streams program (with whole Java interpreter)

This second paragraph is used to stop the Kafka Streams program launched by the previous paragraph
Unfortunately, since programs run through the Java interpreter are executed in the interpreter JVM itself, and because the name of the class above is regenerated at compile time (which makes it impossible for instance to use status variables in another paragraph), an artifice needs to be found to stop it.
So here we’re using a control file whose deletion forces stop the kafka stream program above

paragraphs.text:
%md

## 3. Display messages on kafka output topic using command line kafka consummer

This paragraph used the command line kafka consummer to display results of the Word Cound Kafka Streams sample program

msg.data:
3. Display messages on kafka output topic using command line kafka consummer

This paragraph used the command line kafka consummer to display results of the Word Cound Kafka Streams sample program

paragraphs.text:
%sh

# This is to make sure everything is properly killed when one cancels the paragraph
trap "echo 'Killing shell and all children' && kill $(ps -o pid= --ppid $$)" INT TERM HUP

# Make sure to start asynchronously otherwise the trapè can't kick in
/usr/local/bin/kafka-console-consumer.sh --topic streams-wordcount-output \
        --bootstrap-server kafka.eskimo.svc.cluster.eskimo:9092 \
        --property print.key=true \
        --timeout-ms 300000 \
        --property value.deserializer=org.apache.kafka.common.serialization.LongDeserializer &
export KAFKA_CONSUMER=$!
#        --from-beginning \        

# Wait for the trap to kill it all
wait $KAFKA_CONSUMER

%md

## 4. Send messages to kafka streams program using zeppelin variable

This paragraèh creates a text box where the user can input some text to be sent to the Word Cound Kafka Streams sample program.

msg.data:
4. Send messages to kafka streams program using zeppelin variable

This paragraèh creates a text box where the user can input some text to be sent to the Word Cound Kafka Streams sample program.

params.input: some additional text with some more words
